All but one of these programs is drama. The one exception is Program #11, "A
Dialogue on Toleration,” which is an imaginary conversation between John Locke and
the third Earl of Shaftesbury. Please note the "Dates of expiry." Programs should
not be broadcast after these dates. Times given are approximate.
The tape recordings should be returned to, or traded with, the NAEB Radio Net¬
work (NOT BBC).

ill (Oct. 9) The Rivals - By Richard Brinsley Sheridan, adapted for radio
and produced by Martyn C. Webster. As Sheridan*s first play,
it was produced at Covent Garden in 1775 when the author was
only twenty-three. It was withdrawn as a failure; but after
the replacement of an unpopular actor in the part of Sir
Lucius 0*Trigger, it was immediately successful and is still
one of the most popular comedies in the English language.
Date of expiry: July 1, *57. Time: 89:1|6.
[|2 (Oct. 16) A Month in the Country - Margaret Leighton stars in this play
by Ivan Turgenev. "A Month in the Country," considered
Turgenev*s masterpiece, reflects the carefree mood of a
landed gentry still reasonably prosperous in the period in
which he wrote. The comedy of a Russian holiday, it tells
of the rivalry between a married woman and an unattached girl
for the same young man. Released previously in Fall 195U.
Date of expiry: Feb. 13 *56. Time: 88:35*
U3 (Oct. 23) An Ideal Husband - The comedy by Oscar Wilde, adapted for
broadcasting by Gilbert Travers Thomas, and produced by Val
Gielgud. The play, which was first performed in London in
1895, is set within the circle of sophisticated Victorian
society into which the brilliant adventuress, Mrs. Cheveley,
has contrived an introduction. Her knowledge that the wealth
and the distinguished Foreign Office career of Sir Robert
Chiltern are founded on his sale of a Cabinet secret is her
means of forcing him to suppress the official report on a po¬
litical and financial swindle. Date of expiry: Aug. 22 *57.
